Group

A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Normal Subgroup
A subgroup $H \subset G$ is called a normal subgroup of $G$ if $aH = Ha$ for all $a \in G$, i.e., if for each element $a \in G$ the associated left and right cosets of $H$ in $G$ coincide.
Polynomial Ring

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
Sum of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Prime Ideal
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.
Free system of generators (basis)

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Separable Polynomial
A separable polynomial is a polynomial that has distinct roots in its splitting field, i.e., all roots are simple.
Finite Ring Homomorphism

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is finite if $B$ is a finite $A$-module under $\varphi$. This is also referred to as $B$ being finite over $A$ or, if $\varphi$ is an inclusion homomorphism, that the extension $A \hookrightarrow B$ is finite.
Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).
Stabilizer
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.
Normalizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
Image of Map
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A normal subgroup is a specific type of subgroup within a group. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a normal subgroup is.

The definition of a polynomial ring requires the concept of a commutative ring, which is a specific type of ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a polynomial ring is.
The sum of ideals is defined within the context of a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what the sum of ideals is.
A prime ideal is a specific type of ideal within a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a prime ideal is.
A free system of generators (basis) is defined within the context of an A-module. Therefore, the concept of a module must be defined to understand what a free system of generators is.
A separable polynomial is a specific type of polynomial. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial must be defined to understand what a separable polynomial is.
A finite ring homomorphism is defined in the context of ring homomorphisms. Therefore, the concept of a ring homomorphism must be defined to understand what a finite ring homomorphism is.

The splitting field of a family of polynomials is defined in the context of polynomials and fields. Therefore, the concepts of polynomials and fields must be defined to understand what a splitting field is.
The stabilizer is defined in the context of a group action. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a stabilizer is.
The normalizer is defined in the context of a group. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a normalizer is.
The image of a map is defined in the context of a function. Therefore, the concept of a function must be defined to understand what the image of a map is.
